channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Immigration rule. Heat wave. Putin visit. Mark Robinson. Social media warning. Ian McKellen. NBA Finals. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Boston Celtics beat Dallas Mavericks in NBA Finals, securing the franchise’s record 18th championship
item.description: The Celtics won Game 5 on their home floor Monday night to claim their first NBA title since 2008 and cap a dominant postseason in which they went 16-3. Boston moves ahead of the rival Los Angeles Lakers, who pulled even with their 17th championship in 2020.

item.title: President Biden to announce program allowing undocumented immigrants married to U.S. citizens to apply for legal residency
item.description: Biden will unveil the policy Tuesday in one of the most expansive immigration programs of his presidency, according to two federal sources with knowledge of the plans. About 500,000 people are expected to be eligible to apply.

item.title: IRS to enact rules that would prevent businesses and wealthy individuals from manipulating the value of assets to lower their taxes
item.description: The agency wants to crack down on those who repeatedly depreciate the value of their assets. New audits could bring in an extra $5 billion a year.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: I'm married to a ‘secret bigot.’ How do I reconcile the vile things he says?
item.description: I'm married to a ‘secret bigot.’ How do I reconcile the vile things he says?

item.title: A $50 billion pay package in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Putin traveling to North Korea on Tuesday amid concerns about growing military cooperation between the countries
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong Un are expected to pledge public support for each other and rebuff U.S.-led efforts to isolate Russia over its invasion of Ukraine. Moscow is in desperate need of the munitions that North Korea can provide.

item.title: Gaza fighting. Brutal heat. Biden ad. Marijuana pardons. Baby genomes. Screen time. Princess Kate. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: ‘Stereophonic’ and ‘The Outsiders’ win big at the 2024 Tony Awards
item.description: Daniel Radcliffe and Jeremy Strong also took home prizes at the ceremony honoring Broadway’s best.

item.title: Incoming Post editor tied to self-described ‘thief’ who claimed role in his reporting
item.description: Unpublished book drafts and other documents raise questions about Robert Winnett’s journalistic record just months before he is to assume a top newsroom role at The Washington Post.

item.title: Md. governor to pardon more than 175,000 marijuana convictions, one of the nation’s most sweeping clemency acts involving the drug
item.description: The pardons will forgive decades of low-level marijuana possession charges for an estimated 100,000 people in what Gov. Wes Moore (D) said is a step to heal decades of social and economic injustice that disproportionately harm Black and Brown people.

item.title: Bryson DeChambeau wins the U.S. Open for the second time
item.description: DeChambeau, 30, entered Sunday's final round at Pinehurst No. 2 with a three-shot lead. DeChambeau, who joined LIV Golf in 2022, also won the 2020 U.S. Open at Winged Foot.

item.title: A new program allows members of Congress to receive reimbursements without receipts. See how much your representative expensed.
item.description: More than two dozen members of Congress were paid at least $30,000 in addition to their salary last year as part of the program.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Every time you breathe, you could be inhaling microplastics. See how the tiny particles infiltrate organs, threatening our health.
item.description: Scientists are increasingly concerned that microplastics may be linked to growing rates of cancer, heart disease and other chronic illnesses.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: An officer met a teen at Chick-fil-A, then abused her in his police car. Now a judge must decide his punishment.
item.description: The high school student, who’d wanted to be a cop, was assured that the Indiana officer would be held accountable for sexually abusing her. But a Washington Post investigation found hundreds of officers evaded serious consequences for preying on children, even after they admitted to wrongdoing.

item.title: Trump pledged to pardon Jan. 6 rioters. He faces pressure to name names.
item.description: The presumptive Republican nominee’s vow to exercise the clemency powers of the presidency if he returns to office has raised alarms about his support for political violence and touched off private conversations among supporters about how to deliver on his pledge. There is only one known individual rioter Trump has specifically promised to pardon, according to interviews with about a dozen other prominent family members and advocates of those charged for their roles in the attack. His campaign has said he will decide on a “case-by-case” basis without specifying what criteria he would use.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: My friend’s new girlfriend is jealous and sent me abusive messages
item.description: Ask Sahaj: My friend’s new girlfriend is jealous and sent me abusive messages

item.title: Amazon-owned One Medical shifted some care to a call center, leading to patient safety issues, leaked documents reveal
item.description: Since Amazon acquired the primary-care service One Medical, elderly patients have been routed to a call center — staffed partly by contractors with limited training — that failed on more than a dozen occasions to seek immediate attention for callers with urgent symptoms, according to internal documents seen by The Washington Post.

item.title: They’re the nation’s first Black, Muslim, nonbinary state lawmaker. The hard part came after taking office.
item.description: Four years ago, Mauree Turner’s election in one of the most conservative states made history. What they’ve achieved — or failed to achieve — since taking office has come at a high personal cost.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Alex Jones ordered to sell personal assets to pay $1.5 billion to Sandy Hook families but judge dismisses case to shut Infowars
item.description: The ruling, ending a bankruptcy case involving Infowars’s parent company, means Jones’s far-right website will continue to operate at least a little longer, as parents seek the massive damages he owes for falsely claiming that the 2012 school shooting was a hoax.

item.title: Stanford’s top disinformation research group collapses under political and legal attacks
item.description:
The Stanford Internet Observatory, which published some of the most influential analyses on the spread of false information on social media during elections, has shed most of its staff and may shut down.
Just three staffers remain, who will either leave or find roles at Stanford’s Cyber Policy Center, according to eight people familiar with the developments, some of whom spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss internal matters.

item.title: Carolyn Hax is chatting with readers: My husband changed his mind about kids, months after our wedding. Did he trick me?
item.description: Carolyn Hax is chatting with readers: My husband changed his mind about kids, months after our wedding. Did he trick me?

item.title: New rules aimed at protecting transgender students are blocked in four states by a federal court
item.description: The regulations, issued by the Education Department in April, represent its interpretation of Title IX, a half-century-old law that bars discrimination in schools based on sex. The preliminary injunction against the rules applies in Louisiana, Mississippi, Montana and Idaho, though similar challenges are pending in other states. The rules are set to take effect on Aug. 1 and affect every K-12 school, college and university in the country that accepts any type of federal funding.

item.title: House passes $895 billion defense policy bill that targets abortion access and diversity protections, advances other GOP priorities
item.description: The bill, initially hailed by lawmakers who drafted it as a feat of bipartisanship, is certain to set up a clash — and prolonged negotiation — with the Democratic-controlled Senate.

item.title: Supreme Court strikes down Trump-era federal ban on bump stock devices that allow rifles to fire hundreds of bullets per minute
item.description: The case turned on whether bump stocks meet the definition of a machine gun. Federal appeals courts were sharply divided over that question in earlier decisions on the ban’s legality, before the Supreme Court took up the lawsuit.

item.title: U.S. Catholic bishops apologize for church’s role at Indian boarding schools, citing ‘trauma’ for generations of children
item.description: The extraordinary vote represents the most direct expression of regret to date by senior officials in the Catholic Church for its participation in a U.S. government program to systematically strip Native American children of their identities and forcibly assimilate them into White society. It comes weeks after a Washington Post investigation documenting pervasive sexual abuse by Catholic priests at the schools.

item.title: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz.

item.title: Abortion pills. IVF vote. Evan Gershkovich. Florida flooding. Racism study. NBA Finals. Taylor Swift. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Customers love the Call Your Mother bagel shop in Georgetown. Some neighbors want it closed.
item.description: If the crowds outside got to make the call, the self-described “Jew-ish” deli in a bright pink D.C. rowhome would have no trouble winning officials’ blessing to keep selling its bagels. But owners of neighboring million-dollar rowhouses, citing decades-old zoning laws and a D.C. Court of Appeals ruling, want the shop to stop serving prepared food.

item.title: This ‘Bridgerton’ duo’s long-simmering, friends-to-lovers romance is bringing the heat to Season 3
item.description: Nicola Coughlan and Luke Newton are heating up the Netflix juggernaut, but their path to Shondaland had plenty of bumps. In interviews with The Washington Post, they discuss their journey from out-of-work artists to the diamonds of the season.

item.title: With extreme heat set to roar in, we declare spring over. Here’s how hot it could get next week.
item.description: Starting Monday, every day will probably see highs of at least 90, with the possibility of temperatures approaching 100 during the week’s second half. It could rank among the hottest weeks in several years.

item.title: Senate Republicans block consideration of bill to protect access to in vitro fertilization. See how every lawmaker voted.
item.description: The measure needed 60 votes to advance and received 48. It was the latest Democratic effort to put Republicans on the defensive amid a broader election-year debate over reproductive health care.

item.title: Live now: The Post’s AI summit, featuring Reid Hoffman, Gen. Mark A. Milley, Maria Ressa, Jen Easterly and more
item.description: Artificial intelligence could herald a massive technology shift that transforms the way we work, live and interact with the world around us. Join The Washington Post for robust discussions about the future of the rapidly evolving technology dominating daily headlines.

item.title: Phoenix Police Department routinely uses excessive force and discriminates based on race, Justice Department probe finds
item.description: A federal civil rights investigation into the Phoenix police found that officers there use unnecessarily dangerous force, fail to provide proper oversight and enforce the law based on race, according to a Justice Department report released Thursday.

item.title: Sen. John Fetterman had a history of speeding tickets and distracted driving before his recent car crash, records show
item.description: Fetterman (D-Pa.) was speeding and at fault for a Sunday morning auto accident in western Maryland, where he rear-ended another driver, a 62-year-old woman who was taken to the hospital in an ambulance, according to a Maryland State Police report. The crash was the latest example of unsafe driving by Fetterman, according to public records and people with knowledge of the situation.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: She’s worried her boyfriend sees her as a sex maid
item.description: Carolyn Hax: She’s worried her boyfriend sees her as a sex maid

item.title: Supreme Court retains access to key abortion medication with procedural ruling, a win for abortion rights after Roe was overturned
item.description: A group of antiabortion doctors challenged the FDA’s regulation of mifepristone, used in more than 60 percent of U.S. abortions. Since the high court overturned Roe v. Wade in 2022, abortion medications have grown increasingly important but have faced court challenges.

item.title: American journalist Evan Gershkovich of the Wall Street Journal to stand trial in Russia on charges of spying for the CIA
item.description: Gershkovich has been detained in Russia for more than a year on spying charges that he, the Journal and the State Department vehemently deny and for which Russian authorities have provided no evidence. Officials previously confirmed that a potential exchange had been in discussion involving Alexei Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, who died in prison, and Vadim Krasikov, a Russian security agent convicted and jailed in Germany on murder charges.

item.title: A hot dog legend in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: G-7 meeting. Trump visit. Interest rates. Southern Baptists. Police abuse. Heat wave. Spicy noodles. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Tesla shareholders re-approve Elon Musk’s 2018 pay package, Musk says
item.description: The Tesla CEO shared the news Wednesday night on X, his social media platform. Though the full results will not be revealed until Thursday’s shareholder meeting, the current tallies appear to resolve a dispute that has loomed over Musk’s future with the company.

item.title: A heat wave in the eastern U.S. could produce dangerously high temperatures for much of next week. See maps of the region at risk.
item.description: A punishing combination of heat and humidity will remain lodged over the East, potentially for an extended period. It’s already been one of the warmest years on record in the region.

item.title: GOP-run House votes to hold Garland in contempt after he refused to turn over Biden interview tapes in classified documents probe
item.description: The vote targeting Attorney General Merrick Garland was a show of Republicans’ displeasure that the Biden administration refuses to turn over audiotapes of President Biden’s interview with federal investigators about classified documents found in his home and former office. The Justice Department has already turned over the transcripts but says handing over the recordings would set a bad precedent.

item.title: Southern Baptists approve measure asking government to ‘restrain’ IVF, hours after narrowly rejecting a total ban on female pastors
item.description: The 14 million-member convention, the country’s second-largest faith group, has been shifting to the right since a conservative insurgency in the 1980s.

item.title: The Fed leaves interest rates unchanged and signals a scaled-back plan to cut rates once this year
item.description: The announcement came just a few hours after an encouraging inflation report beat economists' expectations.

item.title: Howard Fineman dies at 75. The veteran political correspondent brought an analytical approach to coverage at Newsweek and on TV.
item.description: Fineman spent 30 years at Newsweek beginning in 1980, serving as chief political correspondent and deputy Washington bureau chief during the era when the magazine, then owned by The Washington Post, was one of the most widely read newsweeklies in the United States. He was also an analyst for NBC and MSNBC for years and became familiar to television viewers through his appearances on shows including “Hardball With Chris Matthews,” PBS’s “Washington Week in Review” and CNN’s “Capital Gang Sunday.”

item.title: Carolyn Hax: How to curb a ‘growing dislike’ of nephew’s new wife?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: How to curb a ‘growing dislike’ of nephew’s new wife?
